Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: On-farm production of nitrogen fertilizer from air, water, and renewable electricity
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of nitrogen fertilizer on-farm from air, water, and renewable electricity. The $78 B global fertilizer marketplace is served today by this process through a complicated and expensive supply chain to the world’s 4 billion acres of farmland. Once on the farm, the fertilizer is applied in bulk, and more than half of it is lost to gas emissions and runoff, potentially damaging downstream ecosystems and poisoning nearby water supplies. The aim of this proposed technology is to offer an alternative method to produce environmentally sustainable fertilizer. The proposed system uses solar panels as an environmentally friendly power source, and applying fertilizer slowly instead of in bulk mitigates the problems with runoff and gas emissions.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a plasma reactor powered by renewable electricity that converts air and water into nitrates in an aqueous solution. For the past 115 years, fertilizer has been produced using the Haber-Bosch process and now produces nearly one billion tons of carbon dioxide emissions every year. The design of the proposed technology is modular, decreasing the costs and allowing use in remote areas and developing nations. This proposed technology produces nitrogen fertilizer on-site intermittently using the power from the solar module and the inputs of air and water. This technology is tightly integrated with the solar array and the farm’s irrigation system to provide growers with on-demand fertilizer. Preliminary studies indicate that the proposed plasma reactor technology appears to be an economically and environmentally sustainable nitrogen fixing technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nitricity was founded at Stanford University with a mission to decarbonize nitrogen fertilizer. Through the NSF I-Corps Program, the team worked with an industry mentor to reach out to a large number of stakeholders in the agricultural space. The interviewees spanned the breadth of agriculture in the United States and California. From small growers of specialty crops, like the Boysen family for whom the boysenberry is named, to very large fertilizer players like Wilbur-Ellis. The team asked these farmers and stakeholders basic questions about their business, inquiring about pain points and large budget line items. This led to the refinement of a business model canvas, and in particular the discovery of a high value market for sustainable fertilizer and new potential value streams, accelerating the path from research to commercialization.

 

Specifically, Nitricity discovered that many farmers want to control the pH of their soil. In fact, many farmers use dangerous and costly sulfuric acid to achieve this goal today. Nitricity found that they could provide substantial value with their technology (see Figure), on a dollar per acre basis, to farmers today. In addition to this key value proposition, Nitricity learned how farmers budget for fertilizer today and identified a subscription model with a service contract as a way to build a business model that will preserve the farmers line items. Following on these developments, Nitricity has gone on to achieve substantial traction in the market and is continuing to develop the technology and business model. This success will have broader impacts in diversifying America?s fertilizer supply chain and creating jobs in next generation manufacturing. Nitricity is also helping farmers be good stewards of the land. The production and distribution of fertilizer accounts for one percent of carbon emissions and the field emissions that result from the application or overapplication of fertilizer releases about 6% carbon dioxide equivalent emissions in the form of nitrous oxide. Nitricity is addressing all three of these challenges by producing fertilizer on the farm when and where it is needed using only air, water, and renewable electricity.
